fileset.reason: Delegates already exist in .net
Namespaces differs in Java an .NET, so it can't be ported automatically
Class loading has different behaviour on dotnet
Underlying implementation classes not autoportable (e.g. java.text.MessageFormat, java.util.Locale
Underlying implementation classes not autoportable (e.g. java.nio.charset.Charset, java.nio.charset.CharsetEncoder, java.nio.ByteBuffer
Underlying implementation classes not autoportable (e.g. java.util.GregorianCalendar, java.util.Date, java.util.Calendar
Poor java.io.File autoporting possibilities (e.g. File#IsDirectory, File#ListFiles, etc.)
Differences in string split
The way java and .NET works with such data types is different. So right now they can be ported only manually.
DEVSIX-3221 - Ignored because built-in Convert class functionality is used in .NET and the Java test is specific to the Java implementation.
DEVSIX-3221 - The way of working with processes in c# is very different from Java. So it can'not be ported manually
Dictionaries are different in java and .net therefor manual porting is required
SystemUtil is a manual class, and the methods of this class can have input and output other than java despite similar names. Therefore, the test for this class also cannot be ported automatically
Ignored because of different work with standard output on Java and .NET

This class seems to be specific for java and used for getting an instance of an Image from java.awt.Image. In .Net it looks not trivial to port automatically as it needs java.awt.BufferedImage and java.awt.PixelGrabber alternative in .Net. Currently we do not have this functionality in .Net
Class summary is not ported correctly. In this class java.text.DecimalFormat cannot be easily ported. Instead System.Double.ToString method is used to cover the same functionality.

Dispose method without parameters cannot be overriden, instead override base.Dispose method with boolean paramter. '(T) this' expression should be ported into 'this as T'. Problem with porting nullable types (unable to bool? to bool and vice versa. Write method cannot be overridden as the base class doesn't contain such method (keyword virtual should be used instead). There are additional inherited abstract methods that should be implemented (but in java version there is no such implementations)
java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream cannot be trivially ported into MemoryStream
java.nio.channels.FileChannel is not supported in dotnet
java.nio.channels.FileChannel is not supported in dotnet

Read method with parameters is mapped to JRead which cannot be overriden (should be mapped to the Read with parameters). Read method without parameters cannot be overriden and not necessary in dotnet. There are additional inherited abstract methods that should be implemented (but in java version there is no such implementations)
java.util.zip.DeflatorOutputStream should be mapped into System.util.zlib.ZDeflatorOutputStream. Method signatures are not mapped correctly (override issue)
System.Collections needs to be added by addCustomUsingDeclaration
Underlying implementation classes not autoportable (e.g. java.nio.charset.Charset, java.nio.charset.CharsetEncoder, java.nio.ByteBuffer
Java specific class that uses java.nio.ByteBuffer and has no alternative in .Net.
Java very specific class for java.nio.Buffer that uses reflection API
Logic for xml parsers creation is not required in .net
HighPrecisionOutputStream is a manual class, and some tests for this class cannot be ported automatically
Logic of some methods in BC and BCFips differs at Java and .NET.
These classes are used only in Java.
Encrypting and decrypting works differently in fips mode
This test is affected by FIPS Mode, where some encryption features are not supported
This test is ignored as it is not applicable for .net. It is not allowed to mutate a value collection derived from a dictionary in .net.
The structure of covered class differ in Java and .Net
Classes that work with XML parsers that have different implementation in .NET and Java
XMLReader has different implementation in .NET and Java
The Iterator pattern in Java is equivalent to IEnumerable in .NET, but we cannot map them on each other.

Node instances should be handled differently in .NET. We already map org.w3c.dom classes to System.Xml. But in XfaForm we use System.Xml.Linq, also in API. Making XfaForm autoportable requires API changes and a lot of time if possible at all
Test classes for testing xml security. They create the XML parser instance and xml parsers have different implementation in .NET and Java
ProviderDigest class exists only on Java.
BouncyCastleDigest class differs in Java and .NET.
KeyStoreUtil class exists only on Java.
Logic of some methods in SignUtils differs at Java and .NET. See SignUtils#getCertificates.
Java.Security does not exist in .net
KeyPurposeId creation logic is different in java and .NET
Date and DateTime UTC time constructors difference in Java and .NET
Some bouncycastle related objects creation is differ in Java and .NET
UNDEFINED_TIMESTAMP_DATE has a different type in Java and .NET
DigestAlgorithms#digest return different results on Java and .NET. On .NET byte can be only positive value.
SignatureMechanisms.getAlgorithm works differently for passed oid = null
Some of the algorithms are not supported on .NET and the result is thus different. The tests with the identical result are in PdfPKCS7Test.
Different implementation on .NET and java
.pem files reading logic is different in java and .net
EnumSet generics mapping problems
Ignored because in .Net we need to have inner List rather than extending from one
Ignored because in .Net we need to use usual search instead of binary
Ignored because in .Net we need to have inner Stream rather than extending from one
Ignored because in .Net we need to use custom BufferedReader
Ignored due to differences in Iterator / Enumerator logic
Ignored due to differences in Pattern / Regex logic
LimitedInputStream extends InputStream, which has different interfaces in Java and .NET
The ignore is added here because the work with absolute path and URI is not autoportable.
InputStream has different interfaces in Java and .NET
Default types of standard output, e.g. Console.Out and System.out, differ between Java and .NET
The ignore is added here due to java.awt is not expected to be ported
There's no serialization functionality in .Net, so there's no sense in this test class in .Net version
There's no serialization functionality in .Net, so there's no sense in this test class in .Net version
Files related to timestamp signatures comparing shall be ignored since they are different in java and .Net
Bug in java version, not in sharp version, therefor a separate reference file is needed see DEVSIX-6752
